source_text: Issac Davis @davisissac AetherAuth Implementation Guide: Open-Access Research Context and Critical Analysis 2 Issac Davis - SCBE-AETHERMOORE + Spiralverse - mid morning review Two lanes: AI Governance (Engineers) SCBE-AETHERMOORE - geometric + cryptographic governance for autonomous agents Kernel / docs / demos: SCBE-AETHERMOORE Six Tongues + GeoSeal CLI (MIT): six-tongues-geoseal Spiralverse Protocol (MIT): spiralverse-protocol PHDM 21D embedding experiments: phdm-21d-embedding Commercial use: SCBE-AETHERMOORE is dual-licensed (non-commercial free; commercial requires a license). See LICENSE in the SCBE-AETHERMOORE repo. Human Learning (K-12 -> GED bridge) Curriculum + structured learning systems (human-first, also usable as tutoring-agent curriculum). Gumroad: aetherdavis.gumroad.com Contact / links X: @davisissac ORCID: 0009-0002-3936-9369 1. Overview of AetherAuth - behavioral proof of system AetherAuth is a component of the SCBE-AETHERMOORE framework (Issac Davis, patent pending #63/961,403), designed as a "behavioral proof system" replacing static OAuth tokens with context-bound cryptographic envelopes. The system embeds 6D context vectors (time, IP, CPU/memory, intent, history) into a Poincaré ball to compute trust rings (CORE r<0.3, OUTER r>0.7, WALL), decrypts vaulted keys only when geometric conditions are met, and produces indistinguishable garbage on mismatch ("Fail

ntext vectors (time, IP, CPU/memory, intent, history) into a Poincaré ball to compute trust rings (CORE r<0.3, OUTER r>0.7, WALL), decrypts vaulted keys only when geometric conditions are met, and produces indistinguishable garbage on mismatch ("Fail-to-Noise"). It extends this with a Calabi-Yau mirror duality for automatic key rotation triggered by environmental flux.​​ This report examines each of these mechanisms through the lens of open-access academic literature, identifying which ideas are well-supported, which are novel, and where critical gaps remain. 2. Poincaré Ball Embeddings for Trust Scoring Established Literature The use of the Poincaré ball model of hyperbolic space for hierarchical and relational embeddings is well-established in machine learning. Nickel & Kiela (2017) introduced Poincaré embeddings for learning hierarchical representations, and subsequent work has expanded this significantly: Balažević et al. (2019), "Multi-relational Poincaré Graph Embeddings," demonstrated that the Poincaré ball can capture multiple simultaneous hierarchies in knowledge graphs, a property directly relevant to AetherAuth's tiered trust rings.​ Shimizu et al. (2021), "Highly Scalable and Provably Accurate Classification in Poincare Balls," established a unified framework for hyperbolic linear classifiers with provably accurate convex optimization.​ Van De Ven et al. (2023), "Po

rust rings.​ Shimizu et al. (2021), "Highly Scalable and Provably Accurate Classification in Poincare Balls," established a unified framework for hyperbolic linear classifiers with provably accurate convex optimization.​ Van De Ven et al. (2023), "Poincaré ResNet," introduced end-to-end residual networks operating entirely in hyperbolic space, showing that visual representations can be learned directly in the Poincaré ball.​ Cao et al. (2025), referenced in a 2025 survey on hyperbolic RAG, demonstrated Poincaré ball projections for encoding hierarchical depth.​ A comprehensive 2025 survey on hyperbolic graph embeddings specifically evaluates these models for anomaly detection, demonstrating that "hyperbolic distances" provide enhanced anomaly separability compared to Euclidean baselines. HADNet (2025) at PubMed Central directly applies hyperbolic space transformations for industrial anomaly detection, mapping features from Euclidean to hyperbolic space and showing that the hyperbolic distance metric represents feature distances "more effectively".​ JANUS (2025) explicitly combines Euclidean and hyperbolic representations for node-level anomaly detection, finding that dual-geometry approaches outperform single-geometry baselines.​ Relevance to AetherAuth AetherAuth's use of the Poincaré ball for trust ring classification (CORE/INNER/OUTER/WALL) has solid theoretical grounding. T

vel anomaly detection, finding that dual-geometry approaches outperform single-geometry baselines.​ Relevance to AetherAuth AetherAuth's use of the Poincaré ball for trust ring classification (CORE/INNER/OUTER/WALL) has solid theoretical grounding. The hierarchical nature of access tiers maps naturally to hyperbolic geometry, where distance from the origin grows exponentially near the boundary—aligning with the design's intent to make outer-ring operations exponentially more expensive. Critical Gap However, the prior workspace audit found that AetherAuth's hyperbolic embedding may not provide meaningful security beyond a simple Euclidean distance check. Claude Code audit sessions revealed that a baseline 2-layer Euclidean pipeline achieved AUC 0.984 on subtle attacks, while the full 14-layer pipeline scored only AUC 0.054—worse than random. The hyperbolic transformation appears to be a monotone transform of the Euclidean norm, adding zero information in the tested configuration. This is a critical discrepancy between theoretical elegance and empirical utility.​ 3. Fail-to-Noise and Honey Encryption Established Literature AetherAuth's "Fail-to-Noise" mechanism—where incorrect decryption attempts yield indistinguishable random output rather than error messages—is conceptually related to Honey Encryption (HE), introduced by Juels and Ristenpart (2014): Juels & Ristenpart (2014) de

s "Fail-to-Noise" mechanism—where incorrect decryption attempts yield indistinguishable random output rather than error messages—is conceptually related to Honey Encryption (HE), introduced by Juels and Ristenpart (2014): Juels & Ristenpart (2014) defined honey encryption as producing "ciphertexts that decrypt under incorrect keys to seemingly valid (decoy) messages". A comprehensive review from Queen's University Belfast summarizes: "HE generates a ciphertext which, when decrypted with an invalid key, yields a plausible-looking but invalid plaintext referred to as a honey message".​ Honey Encryption for NLP (arXiv:2010.15985, 2020) extended the concept using differential privacy to generate contextually similar decoy messages, noting that "a gibberish, random assortment of words is not enough to fool an attacker".​ Honeyword security metrics (arXiv:2311.10960, 2023) provided theoretical formulas for flatness and success-number functions in honey techniques.​ Bernoulli Honeywords (arXiv:2212.12759, 2022) proposed symmetric honeyword designs with quantifiable false breach-detection probability.​ A 2025 USENIX paper on "Practically Secure Honey Password Vaults" presents new designs that "generate plausible decoy vaults for incorrect master passwords".​ Relevance to AetherAuth AetherAuth's Fail-to-Noise differs from classical honey encryption in an important way: rather than produ

cure Honey Password Vaults" presents new designs that "generate plausible decoy vaults for incorrect master passwords".​ Relevance to AetherAuth AetherAuth's Fail-to-Noise differs from classical honey encryption in an important way: rather than producing plausible-looking decoy plaintexts, it produces urandom(64).hex()—random hex strings. This is a simpler approach that prevents oracle attacks (the attacker cannot distinguish failure from success) but does not achieve the full HE property of producing semantically plausible decoys. The user's query correctly identifies this as "indistinguishable garbage" rather than honey messages. The AES-GCM construction with context-salted key derivation is sound cryptographic engineering. The use of Additional Authenticated Data (AAD) binding to user identity is standard practice. However, the workspace vulnerability assessment (Page 24 of the Notion workspace) flagged that there is no formal security reduction proving that breaking this context-bound encryption is at least as hard as some well-known hard problem.​ 4. Context-Aware Zero-Trust Authentication Established Literature AetherAuth's approach of using multi-dimensional context vectors for continuous authentication aligns with a growing body of zero-trust research: ZTMAF (arXiv:2506.05355, 2025) presents a "Zero-Trust Mobility-Aware Authentication Framework" that integrates "context

proach of using multi-dimensional context vectors for continuous authentication aligns with a growing body of zero-trust research: ZTMAF (arXiv:2506.05355, 2025) presents a "Zero-Trust Mobility-Aware Authentication Framework" that integrates "context-aware session authentication with a lightweight trust evaluation engine," using behavioral data, contextual metrics like mobility patterns, and continuous verification—closely paralleling AetherAuth's multi-factor context vectors. Zero-Trust Identity Framework for Agentic AI (arXiv:2505.19301, 2025) proposes a framework using Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) and Verifiable Credentials (VCs) with Zero-Knowledge Proofs for privacy-preserving attribute disclosure. Critically, it addresses the same problem space as AetherAuth—securing AI agent interactions—with dynamic fine-grained access control and real-time policy enforcement. Zero-Trust Foundation Models (arXiv:2505.23792, 2025) embeds zero-trust security principles into the lifecycle of foundation models, with four core principles: Least Privilege Access, Continuous Verification, Data Confidentiality and Integrity, and Behavioral Analytics.​ A systematic literature review on ZTA (PMC:12526847, 2025) documents that "Yang Tao et al. designed a fine-grained data access control model with user context recognition based on Zero Trust principles" performing "multi-stage authentication u

tics.​ A systematic literature review on ZTA (PMC:12526847, 2025) documents that "Yang Tao et al. designed a fine-grained data access control model with user context recognition based on Zero Trust principles" performing "multi-stage authentication using environmental parameters and then validates the user's session using behavioral indicators".​ Contrastive Learning for Continuous Touch-Based Authentication (arXiv:2504.17271, 2025) demonstrates behavioral biometrics for continuous authentication using interaction-specific features, conceptually similar to AetherAuth's behavioral intent dimension.​ A 2025 survey on biometric and smart card integration describes Risk-Adaptive MFA using "context-aware triggers: location, device, IP reputation, login time" and "behavioral biometrics: gait, touch dynamics, keystroke rhythm monitored in background"—matching several of AetherAuth's 6D vector dimensions.​ Relevance to AetherAuth AetherAuth's 6D context vector (time, IP, CPU/memory, intent, history) is conceptually aligned with the latest zero-trust research. The innovation lies in how this context is used—embedded into hyperbolic space rather than evaluated by a policy engine. However, unlike peer-reviewed zero-trust frameworks that undergo formal threat modeling and simulation validation (e.g., ZTMAF used NS-3 and SUMO simulations), AetherAuth's security properties rely on simulated

her than evaluated by a policy engine. However, unlike peer-reviewed zero-trust frameworks that undergo formal threat modeling and simulation validation (e.g., ZTMAF used NS-3 and SUMO simulations), AetherAuth's security properties rely on simulated tests rather than formal verification.​ 5. Post-Quantum Lattice-Based Cryptography (Kyber/ML-KEM) Established Literature AetherAuth references Kyber768 and ML-DSA as its post-quantum cryptographic primitives, consistent with NIST's 2024 standardization: NIST FIPS 203 (August 2024) standardized ML-KEM (Module-Lattice-Based Key-Encapsulation Mechanism) based on CRYSTALS-Kyber. NIST FIPS 204 (August 2024) standardized ML-DSA (Module-Lattice-Based Digital Signature Algorithm) based on CRYSTALS-Dilithium.​ Post-Quantum AKE from Ideal Lattices (NIST workshop paper, Ding et al.) demonstrated practical provably secure two-pass authenticated key exchange from ideal lattices with security based on Ring-LWE hardness.​ PeerJ (2025) published an "Efficient unified architecture for post-quantum cryptography" covering both ML-KEM and ML-DSA implementations.​ Side-channel analysis continues to be an active area: a 2025 IEEE paper demonstrated that Chebyshev filtering can reduce attack success rates against Kyber from 96% to 61%, and an improved two-step attack (arXiv:2407.06942, 2025) showed that full secret key recovery is possible with fewer powe

ive area: a 2025 IEEE paper demonstrated that Chebyshev filtering can reduce attack success rates against Kyber from 96% to 61%, and an improved two-step attack (arXiv:2407.06942, 2025) showed that full secret key recovery is possible with fewer power traces. Critical Gap in AetherAuth The prior workspace audit identified that AetherAuth's Kyber/Dilithium integration is simulated with os.urandom(), not real post-quantum cryptography. The Implementation Proof Package (Page 26 of the workspace) explicitly acknowledges this. Until these simulated components are replaced with actual implementations from libraries like liboqs (Open Quantum Safe), the "post-quantum" designation is aspirational rather than functional.​ 6. Calabi-Yau Manifold Mirror Duality for Key Rotation Established Literature The Calabi-Yau mirror duality extension is the most exotic component of AetherAuth. Academic work connecting Calabi-Yau geometry to cryptography is extremely limited but does exist: Z-Sigil (arXiv:2601.10883, January 2026) by Andrea Rondelli introduces a public-key cryptographic algorithm operating "over the tangent fiber bundle of a compact Calabi-Yau manifold, where cryptographic keys are elements of vector tangent fibers." This is the closest published work to AetherAuth's mirror duality concept, using continuous geometric structures for quantum-resistant key spaces. In string theory, Calab

-Yau manifold, where cryptographic keys are elements of vector tangent fibers." This is the closest published work to AetherAuth's mirror duality concept, using continuous geometric structures for quantum-resistant key spaces. In string theory, Calabi-Yau mirror symmetry exchanges Hodge numbers h1,1↔h2,1h1,1↔h2,1, preserving topological invariants like the Euler characteristic. This is the mathematical foundation AetherAuth claims to use for key rotation. Assessment AetherAuth's mirror duality for key rotation—where keys on one Calabi-Yau manifold swap to a mirror manifold on flux events—is creative but highly speculative. The Z-Sigil paper shows that Calabi-Yau-based cryptography is being explored academically, but:​ Z-Sigil uses the tangent fiber bundle structure, not mirror symmetry for key rotation. No published work demonstrates that mirror duality provides security advantages for key management. The user's query mentions verification via Euler characteristic invariance χ(X)=χ(Y)χ(X)=χ(Y), which is mathematically correct for Calabi-Yau mirror pairs but has not been validated as a cryptographic equivalence check. The hysteresis mechanism (swap only if flux > 0.5 for 3 cycles) is a practical engineering safeguard against oscillation, but there is no formal analysis of its security properties. 7. Sacred Tongues / Conlang-Based Encoding Vulnerability Assessment The user's quer

mechanism (swap only if flux > 0.5 for 3 cycles) is a practical engineering safeguard against oscillation, but there is no formal analysis of its security properties. 7. Sacred Tongues / Conlang-Based Encoding Vulnerability Assessment The user's query references SS1 (Sacred Tongue) encoding for key routing and audit markers. The workspace's own vulnerability assessment (Page 24) flagged this as the most critical weakness: "Linguistic Layer = Security Theater (conlangs crackable with 500 examples)". This self-assessment is consistent with established cryptographic principles—security through obscurity (including constructed languages) provides no formal guarantees. The SS1 layer appears to serve an observability/auditability function (human-readable phase markers like "ko:zar'un") rather than a security function, which is a valid use case if clearly distinguished.​ 8. Consolidated Assessment What Is Well-Grounded ComponentAcademic SupportKey ReferencesPoincaré ball for hierarchical embeddingsStrong (100+ papers since 2017)Balažević et al. 2019​, Poincaré ResNet 2023​Honey-like fail-to-noiseModerate (HE well-studied, but AetherAuth's variant is simpler)Juels & Ristenpart 2014​, USENIX 2025​Context-aware zero-trust authStrong (active 2024-2025 research area)ZTMAF 2025​, ZT-AI 2025​ML-KEM/ML-DSA post-quantum cryptoVery strong (NIST standardized Aug 2024)FIPS 203​, PeerJ 2025​Hyperb

variant is simpler)Juels & Ristenpart 2014​, USENIX 2025​Context-aware zero-trust authStrong (active 2024-2025 research area)ZTMAF 2025​, ZT-AI 2025​ML-KEM/ML-DSA post-quantum cryptoVery strong (NIST standardized Aug 2024)FIPS 203​, PeerJ 2025​Hyperbolic anomaly detectionGrowing (2024-2025 emerging area)HADNet 2025​, JANUS 2025​Calabi-Yau in cryptographyVery limited (1 paper, Jan 2026)Z-Sigil​ What Needs Attention No formal security reduction: The vulnerability assessment correctly notes there is no proof that breaking AetherAuth's context-bound encryption is reducible to a known hard problem.​ Simulated PQC: Kyber/Dilithium are os.urandom() stubs, not real implementations.​ Hyperbolic vs. Euclidean equivalence: Audit found hyperbolic scoring adds zero information over Euclidean distance in tested configurations.​ BFT formula error: Uses 2f+1 (crash fault tolerance) instead of 3f+1 (Byzantine fault tolerance).​ Fabricated traction metrics: GitHub claims (47 stars) vs. actual (1 star); non-existent PyPI package.​ Patent H(6,1.5) discrepancy: Patent correctly states 1,838×, but marketing materials claim 518,400× and 2,184,164× from different formulas.​ Recommendations for Academic Credibility Replace os.urandom() stubs with liboqs (Open Quantum Safe) for real post-quantum cryptography. Commission formal cryptanalysis of the fail-to-noise property, ideally with a security reductio

fferent formulas.​ Recommendations for Academic Credibility Replace os.urandom() stubs with liboqs (Open Quantum Safe) for real post-quantum cryptography. Commission formal cryptanalysis of the fail-to-noise property, ideally with a security reduction. Benchmark hyperbolic vs. Euclidean baselines to demonstrate that geometric embedding adds measurable security value. Separate the mathematical framework paper from marketing materials and submit to a peer-reviewed venue. The Calabi-Yau mirror duality is the most novel component—consider writing it up as a standalone theoretical contribution with formal security analysis. 9.
